BUT here these models are just false for covid: experimentally it has been observed that the WAVES WERE CAUSED BY VARIANTS/mutants and not at all or just marginally because of social distancing stopping. In 2022 we now observed that immunity is lost very fast, and that cross immunity is weak from one variant to the next.


The real mechanism for a covid wave extinction is still not a scientific consensus: the heard immunity, either natural or by vaccine is not the only candidate to explain the wave stopping.
Very detailled PCR observations over the last 2 years are strongly suggesting that a variant is genetically weakened during its propagation/replication until it is unable to propagate anymore, thus stopping the wave. And also that eventually new variants comes from recombinations, not really mutations.

And also that animals such as furets and felines are now endemic reservoirs. All those new experimental facts are game changer for this kind of mathematical models interpretation.
The parameters of those SEIR models are very off, the models are forced to fit the real epidemics plot but is is just a false positive result. This is well know issue in chemical kinetics or plasma kinetics models.

I like your toy model. Ideas I would suggest: Splitting the R group into a green Recovered group and a gray Deceased group. Green is temporary and wears off after some time. When a green person gets pinged by a red or yellow person, their timer resets. If they don't get pinged in long enough time, they go back to being blue. This represents novel strains evolving. Someone constantly exposed to the disease through the evolution of the novel strain maintains their immunity to the evolving strain, while someone who hasn't been exposed in a while becomes susceptible to those changes. And any yellow people will of course become green instead of gray when the infection runs its course, since not having symptoms means they won't die. And you could make the rate at which people turn green or gray after being red depend on how full the hospitals are at any moment. Red people who are at risk of dying turn purple, and if they can get into a hospital they have a very good chance to turn green and leave the hospital. But if they can't then they have a very high risk to turn gray. This makes it actually matter if there's a long tail or not, and can help compare what approaches are best given that the goal is to minimize the total number of times that people turn purple. It may turn out that various means of "slowing the spread" end up being detrimental in the long run because you're allowing the strain to avoid burning itself out for longer, so people recover and survive long enough to lose their immunity and get infected again.

Travel restrictions are pretty much only good if you also take other precautions like quarantines when it does break through. Even the most unlikely illegal border crossings still happen pretty often. The spread from South Korea to North Korea happened when only 0.001% of the South was likely infected, suggesting that if the North only had a 50/50 chance of finding the case, and this happened only 6 months after the South's first infection, that there must be hundreds of thousands of trips from South Korea to North Korea a year or COVID just had Dream luck getting into the DPRK.

And since South Korea isn't losing half a million people a year to migration into North Korea (which would be roughly as many as are born and die in the country combined, and very easy to notice), that also implies that almost all of these journeys are two way trips. That is, someone going from South Korea to North Korea and back to South Korea. Be they spies, smugglers, or people trying to see their family in the other Korea.

Question to you math junkies - shower thought. Also in relation to 10:28. Now that a lot of places are loosening up, the bars in my country can open the doors again as long as they can assure everyone is keeping 1,5m distance. I was thinking, what would be the optimal formula to calculate how many people you can fit in a given space, stating that they must be able to move freely and not enter their 'personal space'? To me it feels like a "circle packing" problem, but you know you cannot fill the entire area because that will prevent them from moving 'freely'. According to event safety institute a moving person takes up about 55/80cm so adding 75cm on both sides will be ((55+75+75)*(80+75+75)) = 4,7 square meter of space per person or to go back to the circle (sqrt 4,7 / 2 =) 1,08 radius per person. Then knowing that, how do we get a optimum of people inside vs them being able to move 'freely' ?

I really like your content but I have some serious criticisms of your numbers here.

1) You basically don't even factor the vast majority (80-90%) who contract CV-19 but show no signs and keep spreading it

2) Age is a massive factor, all dots (infected) are not equal

3) Testing is not instant, there is a huge lag. You generally only test those that are showing (serious) signs of illness and by then they have already spread the virus to many people. Also testing has a fairly high failure rate and thus infected people stay out in the public, spreading the virus.

4) Masks make no difference but social insistence will at best slow to long term infection rate but not lessen it as we can't avoid one another for long periods of time (months/years) as is proven

Basically, by math, yes... you can find ways to defuse the virus but that's not how reality works. You can't test 350 million Americans instantly nor can you test infected people instantly. It's also not possible to just "remove" people from everyone else for many reasons, including the process and place where these people would be moved too... around other people...

Again, I like your content but CV-19 went as about expected to me. The number of deaths has been inflated and the number of infected has been massively under represented. There was no stopping cv-19 anywhere in the world, simply at best slowing the inevitable. yes you can shut down your country, destroy it's entire economic system and destroy countless lives in the process to crunch a meaningless number... but in time the virus would show up again, meaning that shutdown can't end... the infection must run it's course in the case of cv-19.

In closing it's not like it mattered in America anyways. During the height of the pandemic we have millions upon millions of people shoulder to shoulder in the streets protesting and rioting everyday.night for 7 months... It's simply not possible to slow the spread with that happening, and it did happen... and while my goal is not to be political, Democrats supported it because they felt it would help them win an election... meaning deaths were ok as long as it got them power... and you just can't mathematically quantify that in your numbers.

There are few big central hubs and anyway not everyone converge there; indeed there are several hubs (many more small than big) where subgroups may interact; then there are shared routes (public transportation as "mobile" hubs). Accessing hubs can be controlled, in time and density, before going to full lockdown. Likely it is easier to find a less impacting behavior to stop the spreading of agents because the real  nature of social interaction is so complex, and not in spite of it being so complex. Also, if the agents are mostly causing mild symptoms and affect hard only specific groups, these need to be protected more effectively, and there are no strong reasons to enforce countermeasures which have a so large impact on everybody. Few big "central hubs" can be cut off, smaller hubs controlled (basic rules as masks and handwashing, limited accesses on a larger time - the opposite of what is done somewhere), people at higher risk must limit themselves more than others. Letting agents circulate is good - not at the beginning and not if you count the deaths as unbearable (let the world population grow and become older as we are doing now, and we'll see what the future will be in term of deaths and "social distancing"...). Stopping them so hard is something really new, and we don't know exactly where it's bringing us, but we do know that we must be grateful that we hadn't these needs in ancient times, otherwise we would have changed  our same evolution - and I bet we wouldn't have been better: we would have been weaker, and less smart. Simple SIR models don't work.  Actually a lot of modelling has recently been done by physicists working in the field of statistical physics because the concepts and mathematical tools are similar.  For example there is a direct mapping betwen the disease spread and percolation phenomena in condensed matter physics. Unfortunately the models appear extremely sensitive to the topology of the human interaction network and the available databases don't give a sufficient picture of this topology to allow for precise forecasts.  For example such topology can be defined by a function n(k) giving the average number n of individuals that have interactions with k other persons,  it happens however that simulations are extremely sensitive to the existence of any localized peaks in this function, translating the existence of "hubs" i.e. single individuals having hundreds of contacts with other people.  Though, the interest of such simulations is to show some quite non-intuitive results on the effectiveness of various sanitary measures and restrictions.

I would really like to see the tally of deaths in each simulation. Maybe Grant didn't want to be so morbid, but viewing this in September 2020 makes me wonder how devastating it would have been if we had done literally nothing at all to slow the spread of this pandemic. Clearly the disease would have swept through the entire population and almost every single one of us would have contracted it and either died or recovered. That, plus the hospitals and their staff would have been overwhelmed, to put it lightly, causing who knows how many corollary deaths.

But the bright side of this gruesome thought experiment is that the pandemic would be way behind us by now. So, my big question is: how do the total number of deaths in the "let it rage like wildfire" scenario compare to the total projected number that we will arrive at by the time we've finished a year or more of social distancing and mask wearing and maybe even getting a vaccine? I'm sure the numbers differ by at least an order of magnitude, but I'd like to know a more exact ratio.

The Key Takeaways, if you need it for class btw....

1. The growth rate is very sensitive to:

# of daily interactions

Probability of infection

Duration of illness

2. Changes in how many people slip through the tests cause disproportionately large changes to the total number of people infected

3. Social distancing slows the spread, but even small imperfections prolong it

4. Reducing transit between communities, late in the game, has a very limited effect.

5. Shared central locations dramatically speed up the spread

This is really a superlative example of how mathematical modelling should be used. Clearly, from a logical standpoint, in the absence of real-world statistics - and good quality statistics at that - no model can be made to serve as a predictor of the future. But what CAN be done is what has been done here - by making various assumptions of what is happening we can develop valuable insights in to what is important and what is not when formulating rules for public behaviour.

This particular work rightly focuses on what common sense would indicate are important factors of social behaviour and protocols for handling the sick. What would also be interesting is some computer simulation of the physical process of virus transmission by aerosol. This is mainly a physics problem. Results could be used to refine our ideas of what constitutes effective social distancing for instance, or whether it is safer to be in hot humid air or cold and dry .....

Awesome video!
I’d like to comment on the central hubs and the asymptomatic people.
- Central hubs: I see that there are fundamentally different types of hubs (let me call it social gathering hot spots): markets (with limited intimate contact between participants); sport events (stadiums, where after a game supporters will hug each other and go out to drink some biers in large groups); and pubs, bars,discotheques (where people get physically very close to a large number of other people). I’d believe that the R on every of these types of hot spots is very different, so to determine what kind of event should be allowed at a given phase of a lockdown phase, it would be interesting to simulate them separately.
- Rate of infection: I wonder if asymptomatic people (some of the yellow dots in your simulation), are as infectious as those that have symptoms (and sneeze and caught). Not sure how much this would change the simulations though...

Finally, I have the feeling that mobility is very hard to model accurately. When I look at the concrete cases around me, I see that people do not move socially randomly like mostly made in simulations I’ve seen. Rather, we tend have a large number of contacts inside our immediate family, then a bit less with the colleagues in same the office, finally much less frequently with our friends/sport pals, finally with the rest of the community (in supermarkets, restaurants, bars, etc). In the of the simulations, it’s as if you create another layer of boxes within each community box. Inside those smaller boxes it is very difficult to enforce social distancing, but between them it’s easier to do it (eg close all restaurants and stop sport events, etc). I would expect that one could relax the social distancing rules inside a “micro box” (eg family, close friends, maybe office colleagues) while enforcing strict rules for other interactions (eg in those social hot spots that I mentioned before) and still get similar results that one obtain by asking every single person to observe strict social distancing to absolutely everyone (outside own’s household). (Off course, risk persons need strict social distancing from everyone, in my opinion).
The purpose of all this talk... is that it’s easier for a society to follow some sort of tolerant social rules for a long time rather than very stringent (and certainly very effective) rules. If the rules are very stringent, humans can only follow them for weeks, not months, and start being careless after some time. I live in Switzerland and I can observe that after several weeks of carefully the following social distance rules, recently almost everyone started not to follow them at all...
In any case, huge appraisal for your work !

Spending a lot of time with simulations in my life there is one lesson I learned:
After setting up your base model, the first thing to do is try to show that the assumptions and approximations used are valid. By comparing it to experiments or real-world data, you get a feeling if the simulation predicts whats going on in reality.


You have to be sure about this BEFORE playing around with different parameters and presenting results to the public.
If you skip the step of validation you will never know if there is ANY linkage to reality at all. By this, the pictures and results you are producing are just nice looking colorful pictures.


Skipping the step of validation, but presenting the results and conclusions to a majority of people like me who maybe haven't even done any simulations on their own before is crucial.
After this video it was happening to me as well: I was thinking about how to behave best with this information. But then I realized you did not get in the step of validation.
I know you disclaim in the beginning, of the video you are "not an Epidemiologist". But your mathematical understanding is really impressive to me and you know about simulations! :) 4:30 I am quite sure there were parameters like interaction, probability, which would totally change the picture of the base case. Way more catastrophic or way less, with no need for further parameter studies at all... Normally this is not a bad thing and I know that you did them by the best of your knowledge, but this topic is affecting the lives of all of us.

A major takeaway here is the South Korea type early and highly effective contact tracing is the best solution.  However, there are many problems in bringing such testing online in the US, among them, our large population size, false positives and false negatives, the enormous cost and intrusiveness of contact tracing, the limited availability of effective tests and the time required to receive results.  It would be amazingly helpful to look at some of these variables on the realistic potential for actual contact tracing.

It would be helpful to add to your fabulous models some simple economic costs.  What we need are practical solutions (e.g. no way we have 100% compliance in democracies) that don't kill the host either economically (job loss) or physically (virus).

One point you don't emphasize here is the importance and value of herd immunity.  Those models that leave high numbers of unexposed people are seen as better than those where large proportions of the "herd" are now immune.  Given that the world itself is the reservoir for this virus and also the current wide spread, eradication seems impossible until herd immunity is reached.  Thus, reasonably strict social distancing merely prolongs the spread of the virus - an admirable goal, but with a huge economic cost.

I think there's a small thing that may make a huge difference.
The "removed" people that have actually recovered and developed anti-bodies don't just act as a barrier that prevents further spreading, they actually act as "vacuum cleaners" for the disease. This happens because when spreading the disease you're effectively dispensing viruses into the environment, those viruses will end up travelling to random destinations, getting caught in whatever is present there at the moment. So, if someone who has developed antibodies is present, they will take in a portion of the viral load. Which means that they'll not only be a wall that prevents further spreading, but they'll also reduce the probability of people who're nearby of getting infected from that source (since now there's less viral load there).

I'm also interested in seeing what other behaviours could add to that simulation, like houses with multiple people, making sick people stay at home, different spread rates and death rates for certain demographics. (For example, populations of old people having a higher chance of developing harsh symptoms and becoming more infectious as well).

Disclaimer: I'm no epidemiologist or health worker, these are all just things I've learned from interviews with epidemiologists and virologists, etc. The things I'm saying in this comment (as well as the model in the video) should not be taken as proof of what is going to happen or the impact of certain measures. Our models may be deeply flawed or based on wrong assumptions, because the real world is a complicated thing, and at the end of the day, simulations are always simplified versions of the real world. Sometimes they might be over-simplified, and thus yield inaccurate results. Stay safe and don't freak out too much.

My sense is that, no matter how much quarantine or distancing, we'll slow things down so as not to overwhelm the healthcare system, but flattened curves can still have similar areas under the curve.


The only change on death rates will happen at the overwhelm levels. And don't think we're actually going to have that happen in the US as things are pacing out. The issue is how many will ULTIMATELY be infected. (And, of course, what measures we have in place to help them once infected) Don't think we'll ever eliminate infection sources once people are released. Then, naturally, the question is how many does one need to spread things out again. How many did we need in the first place?


Also, not very sanguine about vaccines, nor would I probably take one if made available. We have other strategies, like ozone, that can manage infection quite well, as it did with Ebola.


Another thing: testing right now really sucks. Cross-reactivity so you get false positives. Sampling errors leading to false negatives as do a number of other factors.


Really don't see the TOTAL death numbers changing much even if we prolong an inevitably leaky quarantine. The answer is herd immunity. And the more you keep locked up, the longer it's going to take to achieve that and the more susceptibles you're going to release back into the population to infect.


How will we tamp down death rates: smarter treatments and better prevention. Many strategies coming online for that.


MOST IMPORTANT, though: it is exceedingly STUPID to simply focus on death rates. As horrible as these are, they're still rather low numbers if you sum even worldwide. Now, what about the CONSEQUENCES of all the amelioration tactics we're employing shutting entire countries down? Is there nothing to be said about THAT? Why are we all dodging the question and dancing around coming to grips with the REAL CALCULUS? Looking at the entire SYSTEM. I have now watched this video multiple time and I love it, as far as it goes.  I have shown it one-on-one to people as well as capturing it and sending it directly as emails to people.  I am an engineer and I have been frustrated in being unable to convey the information.  Bravo.

However, I would love to see three other metrics.  And I realize that I am asking a lots..

1) instead of having just the infectious, I would like to see it broken out into the 15% which require hospitalization, and the 1/3 of those, 5% of the total, who require admittance to the ICU.  I have not heard any number on how many ICU patients require respirators.
In many of the cases in is important to show how many people require hospitalization.
Many be three shades of pink.

2) I would like to see a flat line that shows the capacity of medical facilities, hospitals. i.e. How many hospital beds.

3) Your model is great for showing how infection rates change; I love it.  However, What I really want to see is how many people are dying.  The lumping of recovered and died together misses the scariness of the graphs.

3a) I would like to see the recovery and the dead separated out.

3b) It is hard to determine what the death rate is.  It seems to range from 1.5 to 10, but it is an asymmetric graph with a mean somewhere around 3.5% (this is a guestimation from what I have seem).  I think this is do able.

3c) However, I would to add something else.  Unfortunately, I have not seen a mortality rate for people in hospital versus those to convalesce at home.  Nonetheless, I have gotten the idea that once you are in the hospital, the mortality rate is 25%.  So, if the 15% of infected people surpasses the the line described in point (2) about, then those extra people have to recover on their own at home.  It it not unreasonable to say that those people have a 80% mortality rate, once again a guess.  Now you can calculate a different mortality rate for those in hospital and those who cannot get into hospital.  With my numbers, the total mortality rate when we are over capacity is ~20% compared to 3.5%.  I wasn’t sure how to calculate the ~20%, so once again a guess.

4) With the changes above it would show how your graph affects thee infection rate, as well as, showing how the mortality rate sky rockets, when the infectious rate requiring hospitalization exceeds the medical capacity.

Thanks for the amazing video! I have some curiosities in my mind that I want to share with you all. They could help enhance the model hopefully.

1. How does fear affect spreading the virus? What if we added to the model a fear factor that is dependent on #infected or #dead. When fear factor is high, the P(infect) would go down because people would pay more attention to hygiene. And other way round: when the virus spread seems to slow down, people are more careless. So called SIRF model (F for fear)

2. There could be a second wave/strain of covid-19. That would mean that all immune persons would be susceptible again. How would that change the model? Just SIR in SIR?

3. I was wondering if adding things such as demographics (old people move less, teens do not obey the rules etc) would make the model more accurate and help for some interesting phenomena to arise

Of course, I could just myself clean the dust out of my c++ simulation engine and start testing these ideas ;)

Cheers, thanks again for making this and stay safe everyone :)

Something that is causing confusion at the current time, is that no-one knows where their nation really is "on the curve" because testing started at different stages and has been triaged in different ways; deadliness varies by a factor of tens of times depending on underlying health and sanitation, and whether the vulnerable elderly are concentrated at the highest-risk locations or not; and asymptomatic infection rates are probably high (even on the "Diamond Princess" they were observed to be above 50%). Therefore, in a country like New Zealand, where the government has been alarmist and imposed a lockdown, the wrong assumption has been that their curve is starting several weeks behind Italy's, when in fact it is probably very close to Italy's in timing but tens of times lower in deadliness, hence belated attention to the issue. NZ does not lack inbound travel from China at all times, China is a major trading partner and source of immigrants; and it is absurd to assume that the virus didn't arrive at least as early as it reached anywhere else in the world.

Classic epidemic spread model .
However, this model and its variants DO NOT include RISK FACTORS that are well determined on the part of the population.
That is the case of the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.
The model does not take into account the critical difference in susceptibility of elements of the population. Although everyone can infect the risk group.
For example, if the risk factor is the name Gervásio and Gervásia, only these groups will have fatalities. If the risk group is only horses, only this one will be reached.
We can, however, generically infer which variants will most affect the risk group, not to mention the agglomerated confinement of family elements with the risk group.
It would be very interesting to include the risk factor in the model.

My only complaint, and I recognize this wasn't your decision to choose this phrase, is the wide spread use of the term 'Social Distancing', when a more accurate way to describe the intended actions would be 'Physical Distancing'. To many people I'm sure the terms could be thought of as interchangeable, but I feel that it presents a negative connotation to socializing, which is easier and more accessible than ever in the digital age. In times like these where we are encouraged to remain physically distant from one another, a stronger effort to encourage digital communications and interactions between people could go a long way to alleviate anxieties from the now greatly reduced amount of social interactions that used to occur in those pre-'Physical Distancing' environments while still respecting the benefits it provides to limiting the stress on our healthcare systems and the increase in potentially saved lives.

I have a hard time wrapping my head around the notion that this is "eradicated" when it stops spreading, as is sometimes mentioned in the video. I think that's the gaping hole I see in all the social distancing discussions: the endgame. Radical social distancing only addresses the initial curve-flattening. Note how some simulations "end" with the big decrease of the red peak, but an enormous blue (susceptible) population remaining? Restarting the simulation at that point with precautions removed is almost the same as never having had them: the rapid exponential growth will play out exactly as it would have, just with a slightly reduced effective population.

I've seen a lot of content discussing how to stop this initial spread and flatten the curve, but far less (none?) modeling what we should do afterward. It's easy to ridicule black and white propositions like "opening up the country by Easter," but we also need a serious answer to this question that isn't "sit at home until a vaccine exists"!

I think it would be fantastic to model post-quarantine phase of our new COVID-filled reality. Like x% of the population returning to work. Or employers splitting people into teams such that they do 1 week on, 1 week off. Or Mon/Tues for group A, Thu/Fri for group B. You probably almost have this with all the parameters you've created... we just need to plug in some hypothetical scenarios that address forms of modified activity vs. simulating various levels of stopping activity.

when "removed" includes "dead" & "recovered with gained immunity", the models are not very useful. the picture depends entirely on the fatality rate. if the fatality rate is low then it's really not so bad (i.e. your annual flu.) since the virus can't be totally eliminated, and social distancing can't be maintained indefinitely, total infection is unavoidable. flattening the curve is just stretching the inevitable, not changing the total area under the curve, and subsequently, given a fatality rate, the number of deaths will be the same. a more useful model would be one that includes medical capacity and a variable fatality rate dependant on availability of medical capacity. then, the reason for social distancing, and consequently the flattening of the curve, should become more apparent

Some people who reject the coronavirus as the cause present ANOTHER single cause---they're falling for the basic con job.


There are people in Wuhan who have pneumonia because of the horrendous air quality in the city. There are people in New York who have ordinary flu-like illness. There are people in Italy who have histories of multiple, long-term, serious health conditions---pneumonia, flu, cardiac problems, kidney problems---made far worse through treatment with toxic drugs. There are people in hospitals around the world who, after being diagnosed with COVID, are dosed with powerful toxic antiviral drugs. There are people on breathing ventilators who are being given too much oxygen and too much pressure---and their lungs collapse. There are perfectly healthy people who are testing positive for the virus because the test is irreparably flawed... All these people are called "COVID cases."

The diagnostic test for the virus spits out false-positive verdicts, and those results are meaningless---but they form a picture of escalating case numbers. And people buy in.

The stage magic trick is easy to see, once you grasp the tactics: Claim to have discovered a new virus. Say it is spreading and needs to be contained. Invent an umbrella label for the epidemic: COVID-19. Start pulling all sorts of people with all sorts of different conditions under the umbrella and say they're all "cases." Use a diagnostic test that will automatically turn out many verdicts of "infected." And you have the illusion of a pandemic... Or you might get this: "No, it's not the coronavirus, it's really 5G technology that's making people sick and killing them." STILL falling for the magic trick. In certain places, 5G might be harming people. Indeed. And some of those people might be labeled as COVID. Yes. But "the whole thing" isn't 5G, because THERE ISN'T ONE WHOLE THING.

One thing I wish we could model is the effect of social distancing on a population. It's easy to dismiss "we can't stand social distancing anymore!" -- especially when people do it to go back to work -- as "so you care more about money than people's lives?" -- but the reality is that people need money to eat, and if people are laid off because their employers can't pay them (or worse, because the employers go out of business), and if they can't find work because everyone else is practicing social distancing, these people are susceptible to death by suicide or drug overdose.

At some point, the number of deaths caused by social distancing is going to match, or perhaps even exceed, the number of deaths caused by the virus itself. Sure, we're not going to reach that point if the disease would otherwise have killed millions. But what about tens of thousands? How do we find the balance between the two effects?

Key takeaways:
#1
The growth rate is very sensitive to:
- Number of daily interactions
- Probability of infection
- Duration of illness.

#2
Changes in how many people slip through the tests cause disproportionately large changes to the total number of people infected.

#3
Social distancing slows the spread but even small imperfections prolong it.

#4
Reducing transit between communities late in the game has a very limited effect.

#5
Shared central locations dramatically speed up the spread.
R: effective reproductive number
R>1 : epidemic
R=1 : endemic
R<1 : decline

Another thing that would greatly improve the efficiency of response is active coordination of response. Ant-like diffusion of response is very slow. You want more like Air Traffic Control, to drive agile active learning in order to be always running micro-experiments to validate interventions.

The ideas spreading ... idea ... isn't really accounted for well.  You don't need urban centers to have ideas spread. Internet, anyone? In fact, one thing that all these models miss is the rapid diffusion of ideas...aka. innovation. You do it a bit, manually in the demo, but you can link in diffusion of innovation quite easily, and it will hugely suppress the diffusion of infection because it can go AHEAD of the infection wave. Innovations include any intervention including behaviors and treatment protocols -- drugs a bit slower, and physical devices that have to be built, even slower, but there are many behavioral innovations that can spread well ahead of the infection wave.

I think it would be more realistic if the central hub were a larger box so that the area of the central hub is at least several times larger than the infection area. If the infection area is approximately the same as the central hub area you get almost guaranteed infection whenever an infected and susceptible individual are in the central hub together. That's like hiding in a closet with an infected person, not very realistic. In a real world central hub like a grocery store, the central hub area is significantly larger than the infection area so that you have a lower probability of infection when an infected and susceptible individual are in the central hub together. I would expect the result in your simulation to be that the central hub would still increase the rate of infection, but not as dramatically. Regardless, these simulations are awesome. Good job!

I think one more strategy you should be adding is "triggering lockdown measure". When the virus is started spreading, one could draw tree diagrams to represent the spreading from patient zeros (roots) to other suspected or infectious cases. With these tree diagrams, we can trace the spreading of the virus more effectively. But once the number of infections is growing too fast, then the tree diagrams could not keep up with the real situation. What we should do in this situation is using the lockdown measure. So, "if the slope of infectious is too steep, the lockdown measure should be activated". With this strategy, we can buy some time to identify suspected and infectious cases and continue updating the tree diagrams. Once the infectious rate is slowing down then we can stop the lockdown.

As the current epidemic evolves, I noticed a question poping up around me that intrigued me for which I have found no real answer yet. When should it be considered safe for recovered people to go back to their normal lives? A lot of people believe that once they recovered, it's fine to go back to work, but my personal intuition tells me the problem is a lot more complicated than that. Viruses like SARS-COV-2 appears to remain transmissible by people even after recovery. Since the main transmission vector comes from touch, while you might ne be infected yourself, you can still move it around surfaces. This tells me that letting recovered people out of quarantine early might trigger a resurgence of cases. I would be very curious to see a transmission factor included for people after recovery in your model to see how this factors in.

I'm kind of surprised there's no slide with all the key takeaways shown at once. Here, I'll fix that!

Key takeaway #1: The growth rate is very sensitive to: the number of daily interactions, the probability of infection, and the duration of illness.
Key takeaway #2: Changes in how many people slip through the tests cause disproportionately large changes to the total number of people infected.
Key takeaway #3: Social distancing slows the spread, but even small imperfections prolong it.
Key takeaway #4: Reducing transit between communities, late in the game, has a very limited effect.
Key takeaway #5: Shared central locations dramatically speed up the spread.

this video is good as it shows the progression of contact spread but is very much simplified as if the world is a petri dish. please rerun the scenario with real-world examples. The first one is to measure the real R-value. You showed the effect of infected being removed/quarantined after one day. That is not happening well in real life. Plus also ppl don’t show symptoms for over a week if that. Plus there is way more than just one central spot. Run the experiment as follows. Have one blue dot moving around the box and there is say 5 HUB boxes. One is a company staff meeting held daily. Another is a coffee shoppe. Third and fourth is a bus to and from work. The fifth is a fitness gym for daily squats. Now have the blue dot turn red and have it visit the 5 hubs daily and check how the virus is transmitted. Run the simulation which no further transmission meaning the one infected can only get others infected. they don’t spread it further. Run that simulation for 14 days and then see what the R-value is. It's going to be WAY WAY WAY higher than ‘2’. That value is a joke. Plus you also need to include a way to simulate lingering virus spread. Not only does one infect another with socializing but also through lingering virus left behind. The person may go the coffee shoppe or fitness center and leave, but the virus is still there airborne for an hour and stays on uncleaned surfaces for close to two weeks infecting other blue dots way way way more than that R=2. The second run of the simulation would be with these same parameters but now with the contagion spreading from infected to infected, again for 2 weeks before they are found to be infected and quarantined. How then does the virus spread? This last one is a “Read World” realistic simulation. AH! Now let’s include the travel of the red dot from one box to another without restrictions. Then run the same simulation with restricting travel from box 1 to box 2, between the two boxes 30 days after the first 10 infections are found in box 1. In reality that would be ~44 days after infection. 14 days of patient 0 moving around infecting others, then the 30-day clock starts. Ignore the fact that the infection is already moved to box 2 way before the travel is limited or cut. Then change the simulation to have the travel cut after 1 day of detecting the virus. That is ~15 days from the first infection. it’s a bit much but can you accept this task?

So healthy people enter the isolation box, get tested negative and return to their natural environment. But since there are many infected in the isolation box, chances are the healthy people might get infected too and carry the infection back to main population.

Key Takeaways
==============
1.
The growth rate is very sensitive to:
- Daily Interactions
- Probability of Infection
- Duration of illness
---------
2.
Changes in how many people slip through the tests cause disproportionately large changes to the total number of people infected.
---------
3.
Social distancing slows the spread, but even small imperfections prolong it.
---------
4.
Reducing transit between communities, late in the game, has a very limited effect.
---------
5.
Shared central locations dramatically speed up the spread.

This video is wonderful. I don't know if you plan to make another video on this topic, but as I am living in Italy I can suggest you other factors to consider for further numerical simulations.
1 - You treated the market as a single point. Going to the same place does not mean that you have direct contact with other people. Moreover, consider that I go on a market which is not more than 70 square meters and they let just 5-7 people in (making long queue just outside, with high social distance between people (like 3 meters between each) - also consider that if people live in families, some just never go to that place (so maybe only 20-25% of the population goes to the market while the rest does not)
Of course we're talking about a market. I can't imagine how such an epidemic may grow again if the government opens the schools again
2 - consider the concrete real problem in Italy which is causing lots of troubles: the number of hospital beds. Regions like Lombardy are completely overloaded with cases and can't afford more of them. I know people leaving in Bergamo (the town most hitten by the virus in Italy) that are left to their house because hospitals can't afford them, and they also reject the request for the covid test by tampon despite showing all of the symptoms). This can be represented by a threshold in your model, after which some other phenomena happen to cause worse shenanigans.
3 - also consider some different scenarios in which the variable is "how long does it take to the government to take measures to prevent the epidemic.

Of course these are just suggestions and if you want to know others, just write directly to me!

@3Blue1Brown I'm not sure the social distancing factor would be a reliable measure of said action. I think it would be better to simply reduce the infection radius, since this did represent the amount of people that you'd come into contact with. A tiny radius would imply minimal contact. In addition, the social distancing factor implies everyone tries to avoid everyone else, which in reality is not the case. Ergo it would be good to see what would happen if you had a distribution of infection radii over the whole population, to see how this would work (thus one could simulate a society where the majority of people follow social distancing protocols, in contrast to one where most people ignore it).

I was wondering whether we could actually use the number of cases to extrapolate the number of infected people (asymptomatic + cases). Assuming that asymptomatic individuals may act as seeds, the sudden appearance of a huge number of infections within a community could be due to a number of undetected infections (e.g. both asymptomatic + people with milder forms of the disease).

Here I am using the concept of 'asymptomatic individuals' to mean individuals who are contagious but who will NEVER show signs and symptoms of COVID-19 (i.e. SARS2+ and COVID-19-). This appears to be the case of younger patients, babies for instance.

What an excellent video! In the words of George Box: "all models are wrong, but some are useful".  None of these models is right but it is possible to learn a lot qualitatively from them.  I've built similar models but added variability on many of the factors (e.g. social distancing, mobility,  infectability, infectiveness, etc.).  These more complex models change the absolute numbers but make little difference to the qualitative results.  Social engineering by governments can use these qualitative responses to help manage the disease progression.

This is a great way to underst the spread of an epidemic. I understand a simulation can't capture all the phenomena. Moreover, weak parameters don't change the big picture.
However, I think one of the strong parameters is missing in the model settings. It is assumed that people in R sample space (recovered or dead) are completely immune to the disease. And hence, the red peak (people with the disease) decay after a certain time as the sample space of people prone to disease decreases. This parameter is true for dead people but it is too idealistic for people who have recovered. Especially in the case of coronavirus where the death rate is 2%.


Hence, it would be interesting to observe the results if recovered patients are also prone to disease with certain relaxed probability.
Would epidemic decay?

Awesome video.
1) To fix both escaping dots and dots getting stuck on boundaries, make your simulating space toroidal. You leave on the left and reappear on the right. Same with top and bottom (you basically transform your square into a doughnut)
2) There is a problem with your quarantine model, which was also present in the famous "Zombie" model of Munz et al 2009. You do no put back the recovered from the quarantine zone to the general population. That is important, because those recovered, who cannot be infected anymore, dampen the infection.

Which brings me to the topic of another video perhaps? Herd Immunity?

I'm a big fan of your channel, but I think there are some significant inaccuracies in your model of Covid. I suspect this is because you used other viruses as a reference for your modeling, particularly for the "identify and isolate" section. This virus is unpresented in it's unbelievably long incubation time, and it's why standard policies for new viruses haven't been working. Covid has a contagious incubation window of on average 6 days (and up to two weeks). This means that 100% of people will spread the virus for a week on average before they can "identify and isolate". I think it's VERY important to get these details correct because these types of videos spread virally and honest mistakes in modeling can completely distort the final message. (In this case identify and isolate is pointless for any location that has even 1 untraced case). Secondly I'd recommend a more accurate model where groups are not all jiggling, but are instead contained in little "clusters" representing homes. Populations are infected because they go to Central locations and occasionally other homes. But, realistically speaking, my neighbor having covid has very little effect on me getting covid. Not disinfecting an Amazon package or going to the supermarket does.

In light of some of the current discussions it would be interesting to see another factor modelled in - the economic output of the population. Make some of the dots 'workers' and measure how much of a workforce you have left if you disable social distancing early on vs trying to maintain it longer. I suspect that the early gains would soon be offset as the workers succumbed to the disease (this would also require modelling 'deaths' in the removed category.)

This may be too complex for such a simple model, so perhaps it would be easier to measure the impact of having workers continue to work in an office environment while infected (and play with the parameters to see how different values (such as time to work after being infected) affect the workforce). I guess you sort of approximate this by treating an 'office' as one of your communities. But an office is more of a hub community - a group of individuals migrate in and out repeatedly.

It would also be interesting to see if having multiple overlapping hubs per community would have an impact. Most people participate in multiple sub communities (school, work, sports teams). But this probably comes out in the wash, and the single hub per community ends up being almost the same.

I have a small nit to pick on key takeaway #4, that reducing transit between communities, late in the game, has a very limited effect. While I don't doubt that this is true as stated, where all twelve communities (in this simulation) waited until late in the game before cutting off all travel between each other, this is NOT the same as asking, "How will one community fare if they preemptively cut off travel with all the others before things get too bad." Stated this way, it is self-evidently true that it is better to cut off travel with neighboring communities as soon as possible, and the community that does it first will fare the best in terms of flattening its infection curve.

This is unrelated to the focus of this video, but I thought it was an interesting observation all the same: in the study of social distancing, the 100% distancing box settles into a shape reminiscent of the grain structure of many solid materials. It's like the people represent individual molecules with their respective repulsive forces, but the population density, boundaries, and initial conditions force some discontinuities that appear as abstract lines or borders between different sections (equivalently, grain boundaries). It seems the math in use here can similarly represent natural, physical phenomena. I think it speaks to the elegance of the solution and the predictability of math.

Although interesting and informative about simulations, what is missed by many is that it is solely based on a bunch of equations, thatattempt to  mimic reality  and in the end generate graphs and animations for someone to promote their particular message. You use probability theory to give the response you are looking for, but during the current situation, rarely do the authorities talk about the huge numbers of test that produce  negative test results. Testing those that are already sick and likely to test positive introduces a bias into any study and changes the the perception. This is similar to cold war simulations, of nuclear war and cause of death, or intentiinal biohazard release into the general population. It is a set of equations used to produce outputs based on specific inputs. The only sure way of testing, is to do the unimaginable, push the button, or release the toxin and monitor the results.  Outside of that, the natural result isn't  the exponential  growth pattern, but a more normal distribution. The curve in this case is quite flat, and injection of increased numbers, without monitoring  the reality and displaying ' the real data '  for public scrutiny,  is just another simulation where input parameters are changed.  If you haven't noticed the cold war and threat of nuclear holocaust has been pretty well proven to have been a sham. So let's stick to reality please, pretty slides, artists conceptions, etc will only impress the dumb and dumbfounded.

Great model, however, my main concern is that the model assumes that once you have been infected, you either die or recover with immunity against the virus. The problem is, in the context of COVID-19, there have been reported cases of second positives, albeit quite rarely. This implies that once you have recovered, there is no guarantee that you would not contract the disease again, possibly causing you to infect more people.

One thing that might improve the quarantining model is to move people back into the population after a while, and simulating different time periods of "looks safe" (no symptoms anymore) vs time infectious. This might show the effect of people self-quarantining, but not realizing that they might be infectious before/after symptoms are visible.

As an epidemiologist, I have to say that your simulations are very impressive, I just love your video. However, a small question: in many diseases, there is not 3 but 4 possible status: (1) Susceptible, (2) Infected but not sick, (3) Sick and (4) Removed. People in stage (2) (we will call them "contaminant") do have the virus but there are not sick yet. So there is no way to put them apart. But then can spread the diseases. In many sicknesses, the "contamination rate" of these people is half of the contamination rate of sick people. That is, if the R0 is 6, a person will infect 2 person when he is (2) contaminant and 4 person when they will be (3)sick.
Is there a way that you model can take that into account?

"even when all the parameters are the same, some runs take three times longer to reach this point than others"
This deserves more than just a side note.
With agents starting at random locations and then moving around randomly, you are likely to end up with a chaotic system.
It cannot be stressed enough how crucial it is to have multiple test runs for each set of parameters.
For some parameter sets, you might end up with almost everybody infected in one run and the infection quickly dying away in another run, just due to random fluctuations.
Virus simulations (as well as economic simulations and weather forecasts for that matter) can be highly susceptible to random noise.

Thank you ThreeBlueOneBrown for this helpful and informative video that really clears up a lot of misconceptions and elucidates rather than exacerbates panic. I've shown this video to my family hoping it calms their fears about so much uncertainty, which I myself still wrestle with when looking at models concerning this pandemic.
One particularly nagging thought is how selective evolutionary pressures such as advantageous mutations can impact both the transmissibility and infectivity of the pathogen. For instance, say the virus undergoes a mutation that confers enhanced spreading and severity (greater binding affinity to receptor sites, novel modes of host cell entry, accelerated viral load production, etc.) In which scenario, one being lacking or ineffectual containment measures resulting in a sharp spike and the other being those that 'flatten the curve', does this new variant have a greater chance of gaining a foothold within the host population? Does the rapid spike make it more difficult for such a more severe strain to spread given that there are few remaining susceptible hosts and it essentially has to compete with the older, less severe version of itself? (An exhaustive r-selection) Could flattening the curve actually create an opportunity for the new strain to potentially exceed containment measures geared towards the weaker version, and infect the sizeable portion of susceptibles without any competition of the sort? This might not be an unimportant question, as even the apparently smallest variables can have major effects in the long run.

Instead of putting the people in a boxes with edges, why not put them in a torus? This is the way Pac-Man behaves when he walks off the edge of the screen, or the way the game Asteroids deals with objects moving off the screen. The benefit of this is that it would eliminate edge effects, which don't seem to have any obvious interpretation. This might particularly have an effect on the model where you add in social distancing. Of course this change in topology would probably have more of an effect for smaller models than large ones with a lot of area.

12:59 I completely disagree with your takeaway that traveling restrictions has a minimal impact...


As one advocating for a lockdown of transversing states and commuting down highways to prevent spread, your simulations don't correspond with the effect that I believe to be observing:


1. How would the other areas be infected if the infected never left the area?
2. People tend to migrate from infected areas to flee it, thereby the ones transversing to new communities might have a higher probability of A. Being infected; and B. Traveling to state hubs, cities that are more densely population like your hot spots.
3. Commuting to a central hub is like a store or commonplace is a form of traveling, which your simulation showed produced detrimental effects; however, why wouldn't travel between states and communities be as extreme? People don't really randomly transition from one place to another, so, in theory, movement between one community and another can be seen as a central place.
4. People don't have enough test kits to truly identify and isolate everyone that is contaminated: NY's strategy seems to be faltering, which is essentially that method; there are far too many people to pluck out the right ones in communities, so wouldn't that have a higher impact on commuting between different ones? If a community isn't doing enough testing and people are fleeing to there from infected outbreaks since it might be safer, wouldn't that exponentially drive up the rate?
5. Once the cities correctly identify people, how wouldn't travel restrictions not have a bigger impact? How are you going to correctly identify new asymptomatic people? Wouldn't it just blow up again like when everyone returned back to their normal life?


It would be interesting to see a simulation where travel restrictions were in place that prevented travel across communities when they had a higher probability of A. Going to denser areas; and B. Being infected. It would also be interesting to see how commuting would factor in tourist attractions and common areas that people visit due to their appeal: I would imagine that this would resemble what is occurring when people were asymptomatic, even to the extent of not taking social distancing seriously, right now.


Restricting travel sounds logical/reasonable and like it would be more effective like anti-cross-contamination measures would be in the food industry.


I think you should reexamine the Travel section, also factoring in how close contact through the traveling might factor into it like on airplanes and buses and cars, where everyone travels together but goes to different locations in the communities.


I feel like downplaying the travel restriction solution when outbreaks are widespread might be detrimental if everyone takes it to heart... It should be revisited to make sure if it's accurate, I think.


UPDATE Also, how would the traveling section do with a greater sampling size in your demonstrated, combined with incorrectly identifying and not testing certain subsections?

At 11:50 I noticed that with extreme social distancing, the "red blob of infection" is concentrated, and thus its "infectious perimeter" (the border between healthy and infected people) grows as square-root of the area of the red blob (which is the number of infected people).
Contrast this with no social distancing, and people just randomly mix together. Then the blob of infection is basically a bunch of little circles, and thus the infectious perimeter grows as the area of the red blob.


So the difference is a factor of square-root, which, combined with exponential growth, could be very significant.

Here’s another idea to simulate: homes
There’s small boxes outside of the main box, and each of those small boxes has 3 dots assigned to them.
Each dot has a ‘role’
1 dot has a ~25% chance to travel to a main area (grocery stores, restaurants etc.) on any day. Make three ‘hubs’ in the big box, with an equal chance for the ‘wonderers’ to travel to
The second dot has a ~75% chance on any day to leave their house, but stay away from the ‘hubs’ and try to avoid other dots.
The third dot has a ~10% chance to leave their house, but they stay right outside it.

Summary of key takeaways:


Takeaway 1 :
- Daily interactions
- Probability of infection
- Duration of illness
These factors greatly affect the rate of spread of the disease

Couple of possible alterations to make to this simulation (albeit quite grim):

1. Split infected into 'carrier' and 'serious', and 'dead'.
2. Give a weighting to certain population demographics based on susceptability to response to the virus (i.e the older you are, the more likely you're 'serious').
3. A variable on the quantitative response of a system to convert those 'serious' into 'recovered' (i.e. healthcare capacity).
4. Repeat using real world figures.

Now, this adds some complexity to the model, but if anyone can do it...I have faith in you.

Only one question I came out of this with: What about a "False Positive" factor?

On the roof, it seemed like a false positive just means that a non-infected never gets infected, so the number of cases goes down proportional to the false positive factor

... except that a non-infected that never gets infected also can't infect people.

Lower false positive factors do mostly nothing, and higher false-positive factors would (probably?) reduce infection rate, because that's one person that does never gets infected and never infects anyone else.

(And a 100% false positive factor is "legally mandatory isolation across the community, to be enforced with armed guards for people who repeatedly break the rule", because that means 100% of people are treated as infected, so 100% of people are isolated)

All these models are fine and dandy, really great work.
But in the real world, things just don't work that way. You can't force people to employ social distancing. You can't forcibly quarantine everyone. You can put restrictions on travel though and close down centers of contact.

I believe the real issue with Corona is that there's actually a high percentage of infectious people out there that don't have symptoms. The onset of symptoms can take a couple of days.
And those that have symptoms are so varied in the severity of those symptoms that less than half of all cases even know they have the virus.

Someone sneezes and coughs a few times during two days but it doesn't get any worse than that. So they never check if they actually got infected or not. And so they keep on moving about spreading the virus.

Basically, there's a lot more yellow in the real world than these simulations portray.

I also have a different solution to the whole problem with Corona.
If you are a healthy adult in your 20's to 50's, you should actually strive to become infected. This group of people are those with the least risk of death. Only between 0.2% and 0.5% in this group actually die from Corona.
So if you basically cut out 65% of the population by having them moved to the recovered pool, these people can still go business as usual.

The ones we need to protect are children, the elderly and those with existing conditions like immune system complications, heart/lung problems and so on.

As it's currently progressing, i fear the "solution" to the epidemic is actually going to prolong the period of people not being productive. And if this period goes on for too long, society as we know it will collapse in on itself and we'll have widespread panics and global total anarchy.

I think it would have been good to add some quite heavy self-isolation to infected people, to make the base case more closely reflect reality. Those who get an illness, even one as mild as a common cold, will usually stay in their homes and avoid shopping while waiting it out. This keeps possible continued infection at that point limited to just the family (who usually won't be kissing or shaking your hand at that point).

And if you look at it that way, where people are always put into isolation to some degree, you'll realize the importance of the time before the isolation sets in. That period where you might have just a sore throat or the sniffles, still healthy enough to go about your business without self-isolating, but sick enough to spread the infection. That was part of the reason why SARS could be stopped, the window was very narrow for that virus, you wouldn't be very contagious until you showed clear symtoms.

It's extremely dangerous that people think, "Oh big deal it'll kill 2-3% of the population and we'll move on and be fine." While yes this is the official approximate death rate this is assuming the healthcare industry DOES NOT GET OVERWHELMED. This nation only had 2.8 million hospital beds before this crisis and even with military support will likely not have more than 4-5 million. With how fast this virus spreads we could see TOTAL INFECTION within just 30 days if we do absolutely nothing to stem the tide. The official hospitalization rate for Covid-19 is ~20% which means that those people will DIE if they don't get hospital care (especially ventilators). If we see total infection within 30 days and a 20% hospitalization rate we could easily need 70 million hospital beds and only have maybe 4 or 5 million. Combine this with the fact that people will continue to have heart attacks, strokes, car accidents, or anything else that needs hospitalization and those people will also die. This means that IN THIS COUNTRY ALONE we will easily see 35-65 million (10-20% of America) people die in the blink of an eye. This should be completely unacceptable to most Americans and I believe if people knew this information they would be treating this far more seriously.

The dots escaping was really funny. I'm no expert in collision detection, but with my experience dealing with such cases I think I know what the problem is.

Back around the last quarter of last year I was taking a game programming class and as a final project I build a (kinda shoddy) physics engine in 2d. The engine consisted of calculating the location of intersection of the travel path of a dot (which becomes a line given some time delta) and a collision surface (a line). So the problem turns into that of finding the intersection of two lines. EZPZ I thought, I did my deal and coded the formula I derived, build a driver program of a dot enclosed within a square. Surprise surprise, the dots were able to escape through the corners.

My reasoning is not lucid enough to think of solutions through math models or anything of the like, so what I did is that I stepped through the logic cycle of the algorithm manually as the "event" was close to happening. It didn't take me long to realize that the problem was that the distance traveled after bouncing on the wall was causing the dot to be placed passed the neighbor wall. I also haven't fixed the problem yet because I thought it was as easy as repeating the collision detection a few times, but then I realized that this is recursive because if the dot collides with enough force or close enough to the corner of two walls then multiple of this "trespassing collision" (as I called them) would happen.

I think I found a related article in stackoverflow where the asker was pointed to a blog of a programmer who solved this problem, but both the math and the code was beyond me. All I know is that it is not trivial to solve.

EDIT: the problem can also happen in straight walls (albeit less often) if acceleration is involved. The same problem as above, the only difference is that the trespassing is now happening with the same wall the original collision happened.

What would also be interesting is a simulation of "ideologies"/"ideas". Say, by "contact", a "convinced" person might convince another person, but the same goes vice versa - a nonconvinced can spread doubt in convinced ones. How would the curve look then?

For example:

- 32 "communities", 4 of which will contain central hubs and 4 of which will contain a central market
- 100% are asymptomatic for 3 days; 80% will show symptoms afterwards
- 70% will be quarantined after 1 day of showing symptoms
- The infection goes away after 14 days
- The infection radius is the same as in this video
- Recovered patients are immune to future infections
- 0.005% of people can go into total isolation ("leave the box") per day

- Travel rate between communities is normal (0.2) until a certain threshold is met (in which case, travel rates will go down by 75%)
- Social Distancing rate is low (20%) until a certain threshold is met (in which case, social distancing goes up to 75%, then 95% if things get nasty)
- Infection rate is high (0.2) until a certain threshold is met (in which case, infection rates are cut in half)
- For the first time only, if the number of active cases falls below a certain threshold, travel rates, social distancing, and infection rates go back to normal

- Certain Threshold: 0.5% of the population is infected

NOTE: The virus's actual asymptomatic period can go up to 14 days, and according to zemerick13, the infection can last a lot longer than 14 days.

Brilliant, as always. It's just so impressive how clearly you can communicate this complexity. A good follow-up, though, would be to model the effects of the key aspect of "flattening the curve", which is to reduce the overall strain on your health system. The metric of "total people infected" is not particularly crucial with Covid-19 (unlike SARS or MERS). The number of fatalities associated with Covid includes those with other acute care needs (heart attack, car accident) who die because the medical equipment/staff is not available. For example, in Bergamo, Italy, an average of 35 people die each March. This year, 31 people were identified as dying of Covid-19 in March. But the total death count is not 66 (average+Covid), but rather 158. There's a lot to unpack in terms of causality, but two other places also show the 6x multiplier.

It's important to note that your definitions of epidemic and endemic is not the one used by public health officials. The terminology is used to define the geographic scale of an illness's sphere of influence.

"Endemic" is the smallest scale, usually just referring to a community or locality facing the illness.
"Outbreak" refers to a slightly larger scale of influence geographically.
"Epidemic" refers to a sudden and rapid spread of illness across vast geographies, though not the whole world. Perhaps a national or international scale.
"Pandemic" refers to a massive epidemic which has spread across most nations in the world. Typically a nearly global event.

EDIT: I've been meaning to make an update to this for a while. So apparently the way our immune systems interact with viral infections specifically is that we remember ones we've contracted before so we don't get sick from them again, but the reason we can contract viruses like the cold and flu multiple times is that they mutate quickly enough that we may be exposed to a new strain that's different enough our immune system doesn't recognize and protect us from it. However, from what I've read, so far Covid19 isn't mutating rapidly enough that we should already be seeing people who've already been infected become infected again, and reports of such are more likely issues in testing or changes in symptomology.

That said, I am still curious about different models with reinfection, just out of curiosity, possibly representing non-viral infections, or with multiple strains.

I've started to realize that coronavirus is pretty close to the perfect virus.
It doesn't do the Plague Inc strategy of being invisible and then mutating into death, but that's not the real world anyway.

But it spreads quickly, is infectious for several days before symptoms, has non-symptomatic people, and is just deadly enough that it can kill you--but harmless enough that people will still go outside with just a cough.
And to top it all off, there's nothing "special" about it. It's not gruesome like ebola. It doesn't paralyze you for life like polio. It's just the flu, except subtly better/worse in every way. And so people feel comfortable. Which makes them not take action soon enough. That's not something you'd usually think of, but it absolutely works to the virus' advantage.

If you want more information on COVID-19 from someone who is an expert, I found this MSRI talk to be quite good: https://youtu.be/MZ957qhzcjI

While here we looked at what you might call an "agent-based" SIR model, if you want to see what it looks like as a set of differential equations, Ben Sparks just did a lovely video on the topic over at Numberphile: https://youtu.be/k6nLfCbAzgo

There are a few reasons I like the agent-based model here, for demo purposes at least. It's a bit easier to understand for those who are not comfortable yet with ODEs, for one. It also conveys how things are not deterministic; no real-world curve will look as smooth as the differential equations. It also makes it way easier to ask questions and bake other assumptions into the model. Introducing things like travel or community centers into the differential equations would get very hairy very quickly. For those who want to go much more deeply into this, the Institute for Disease Modeling has a lot of models free for people to look at and play with.
